story:
Hi there, I'm Joanna.

I am a wife, mother, and artist striving to use my talents to fulfill my God given purpose to be creative, connect with others and worship the Creator.  I have been an artist for as long as I can remember - making observational drawings as early as age 3, and experimenting with every kind of art and craft as I grew older. In college I discovered an intense love for making pottery while earning my BA in Fine Arts.  After graduating I created a small in-home pottery studio and had dreams of turning it into a business. But in the 4 years since graduation, my husband and I have started a family and moved across the country twice, which led me to give up pottery temporarily to focus on being a mother. It's been almost three years since I've thrown at a pottery wheel and it has been an ache, itch and yearning this whole time.

I would not trade my time at home with my daughter for anything. It has been an experience that has grown and challenged me as a woman and forged a inexpressible bond between my daughter and I.  We've been through a lot together, and now it's time for another chapter. My husband will be graduating from the Tucson Fire Academy in January which will give him larger chunks of time to take on parenting responsibilities and allow me time to get back into the studio.

I found the time to start, but making art also takes money and that's where you come in!  I can not do this without you. Your contribution will enable me to step back into the pottery studio and do what I love most - make things with my hands that will be loved and used by others.

Why $2000?

I need $2000 to complete my 6 month pottery residency. Here’s what that amount will cover:

  • $550 - Total cost for 6 months at a local collaborative studio
  • $600 - shipping costs for sending pottery perks back to you who contribute.

  • $690  - for the purchase of clay and other materials..

  • $160 - fees for using IndieGogo as a platform

If this campaign receives over the goal amount, the additional funding will cover storage shelves, more supplies, and longer studio time.  I would love to be in the studio much longer than 6 months and to sell at craft fairs in 2019.  All the money this campaign raises will go towards these goals. 

What’s in it for YOU?

A huge motivating factor in my love of making pottery is the act of handing my pottery over to someone to use and enjoy in whatever way they wish.  There is nothing more beautiful to me than letting go and letting another person add to the story of a piece of pottery I created. In light of this, I have designed the goal of my campaign to include making pottery to send back to my contributors.  For smaller donations, you will receive a drawing by my daughter or handmade card from me. Larger contributions will receive pottery in the mail. I will be making each piece with you in mind. Praying for you by name and thanking God for your support.

Challenges I will face:

There are a few things that I am expecting to be challenging as I step back into this artistic practice.  One is physical. It takes the whole body working together to be able to center and throw well. I am obviously out of practice.  In preparation I have frequenting the gym to strengthen my arms and back but it will take some time once I’m in the studio for my muscle strength and memory to come back.   

It will also take some effort to iron out scheduling and consistency during my residency.  On different days I will have to schedule around my daughter’s sleep schedule, my husbands work schedule and the studio’s available open studio hours. But I am confident that I will be able to succeed in a consistent pottery practice especially because my husband's schedule will have a lot of room for him to support me in this. 

What will happen after the money runs out?

I have budgeted my time and financial goal in such a way that I hope to complete making all of your perks within the first 2-3 months. That will leave the final 3-4 months of my residency to build an inventory.  My hope is to make enough pottery and begin selling that pottery at local craft fairs and online to fund studio time indefinitely. Being a full-time potter and running my own business is my end goal, and this residency is the first step towards my dream future.

Can't Give? Please share! 

If you’ve read this far but you don’t have any extra funds to contribute, please consider helping me out by spreading the word! Share this campaign on any (or all) of your social media accounts and tell people about my project.  Just a quick click can make a huge difference and help me achieve my creative goals.

story:
6-week Summer Artist Residency | Shiro Oni Studio | Onishi, Japan 

From MD to Japan | Why Japan?

For many Western potters like myself, the study of Japanese ceramics is often where our love of clay began. My own studio practice is heavily influenced by Japanese traditions and is specifically focused on designing modern sculptural interpretations of Eastern temple bells. In addition to my long-time dream of traveling throughout Japan to visit temple bell sites, I have a particular interest in learning from rural potters about the Japanese wabi-sabi philosophy + the Mingei folk art movement. While in residency, I hope to immerse myself in Onishi's mountainside community, travel to Shinto shrines and Buddhist temples to continue my Bell Project research, and create a new body of work inspired by this experience. 

Why an Art Residency?

I am honored to have been awarded a spot in the Shiro Oni Studio program for 6 weeks this summer. I will join a group of 10 international artists for a cultural exchange in the community of Onishi, a small Japanese town just 1.5 hrs north of Tokyo. Art residencies are a common practice among artists. They allow artists a dedicated time to fully engage in their work + absorb the influences from the culture they are visiting. Between teaching full time at the high school, part time at the college + being a dad, I find creating my own work for a sustained period of time can be a rare thing. The opportunity to travel to Japan for focused study and studio time is a dream. 

The intensive collaborative experience culminates with a week-long exhibition at the Old Sake Brewery (pictured above) or the Neo-modern Onishi Hall designed by Pritzker Prize-winning architect, Kazuyo Sejima (below).

Why Shiro Oni?

Of all of the residency opportunities I researched, the cultural exchange component of Shiro Oni is one of the things that attracted me most of all. In my Skype interviews, I learned how significant the daily workshops, shared meals + collaboration time with members of the local community become for both artists and townsfolk alike. While I'm very excited for the focused studio time, I am most excited for the exchange + the way this community absorbs and welcomes its Resident Artists and their families.

The Bell Project goes to Japan

Ten years ago, I made my first ceramic temple bells as part of my MFA thesis research project. I chose bells as a long-term design subject because of the symbolic importance they have held throughout history. Bells can be symbols of mindfulness, and the ringing of a bell can help signal the time for tranquil thought and contemplation; a concept especially important in the age of social media and the 24-hour news cycle.

The bells I make range in size from 12"- 26" and each one is a functional sculpture. Design experiments are done to determine the ideal shape, size + firing temperature needed for clear-ringing and unique tones.

The Bell Project has evolved today to focus on conceptual designs that visually address different world issues and symbolically ring away the frustration and fear associated with those problems. Since ceramic objects can survive for tens of thousands of years, I imagine the bells becoming a permanent record of our human experience and hopefully taking with them a message of peace + global compassion for the future.   

A Gift of Solidarity to Onishi

In Japan, I hope to create a new body of work inspired by Onishi, its people, culture, and beautiful mountainside environment. It was once a flourishing industrial town with a bustling silk trade moving up and down the river, however, an economic downturn has left empty buildings and storefronts. Resident Artists set up their studios in these empty spaces + help generate new opportunities for Onishi through exhibitions and gallery talks, which bring visitors to the area.

At the end of my residency, I will be donating a bell installation to the town of Onishi. A BELL WILL BE INSCRIBED WITH THE NAMES OF EACH OF MY CROWDFUNDING PATRONS to build upon the idea of a cultural exchange.

The Journey

We depart for Japan on June 25th. We will spend 2 days in Tokyo before my residency begins on the 28th.  While the majority of my 6 weeks will be devoted to time in the studio, there is a lot more to the trip.

Shiro Oni Studio has established a unique relationship with the town + offers many exciting cultural exchange opportunities for our family to participate in:

  • Pia + Noa (my 3rd + 6th grade daughters) will join the local school kids for nightly TAIKO DRUMMING in preparation for the ONISHI MUSIC FESTIVAL PARADE.
  • My wife, Natasha, will be working on her own PHOTO PROJECT + chronicling our experience (which will be shared with you, our crowdfunding patrons).
  • We will join WEEKLY WORKSHOPS in rope-making, calligraphy, Zen meditation, forestry, river ecology, and more.
  • We will work shifts at the ORGANIC FARM + join local families for NIGHTLY DINNERS.
  • We will participate in several TEA CEREMONIES + end our days with BIKE TRIPS INTO THE MOUNTAINS and SWIMMING IN THE ONISHI RIVER.

And when that is all over, we would like to spend an extra week traveling to the cultural centers of Kyoto + Osaka to complete more temple bell research, visit the National Museums and take a day-trip to the Shigaraki Ceramic Park. 

Crowdfunding Goals

My goal is to raise $3,500 to fund my Art Residency at Shiro Oni Studio (about 1/2 of the projected cost for our family to go). This opportunity came a year earlier than anticipated, so your crowdfunding generosity will certainly help make this become a reality. While the list below is partial, anything we raise will certainly get us moving in the right direction.

1200.00 | Shiro Oni Studio residency fee (studio, house, exhibition space, etc...)

1200.00  x 4  | roundtrip airfare

250.00  | Tokyo accommodations when we arrive

500.00  | travel insurance

500.00  | studio supplies

500.00  | shipping new work back to the US

500.00  | travel to Kyoto, Osaka, Shigaraki + temple sites for research

500.00  | accommodations during week of travel

500.00  | food + incidentals

This is where you come in. By supporting my project + residency, you become an art patron and share in a ceramic artist's journey to Japan. Listed on the right side of this page are different donation levels + when you fund this campaign, your gift also comes with a token of appreciation...PERKS! 

I know that not everyone is financially prepared to fund this kind of campaign, but you can support what I'm doing in other ways as well. Please feel free to share my campaign and get the word out on social media (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, etc...).

Perks

In gratitude for your support of this crowdfunding campaign, I am offering some PERKS that will hopefully connect you to this experience in a meaningful way.  They include:

  • ($25+) Your name inscribed in the Onishi Bell, to be donated to the town at the end of my residency...
  • ($50+) A frameable print of one of Natasha's photographs taken while on our travels...
  • ($100+) A small commemorative bowl created by me and sent to you as a reminder of your patronage...
  • ($500+) A small commemorative bell for you or your company to display in your home, garden or office... 
  • ($1000+) All of the above! A name inscription, a photograph, a bowl + a bell for you ...  

*Please visit my website, BakedClayStudio.com if you'd like to see more of my work + find out what I am currently working on.

story:
Art for the Future

This project supports the implementation of the UNESCO Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) through the creation of a limited series of collectible artwork.

Seventeen original pieces of artwork will be designed and created, representing each of the SDGs. Like the Goals, each piece is interconnected and together make up a whole that is greater than the sum of its parts.

Culture has been recognized as integral to achieving the SDGs, and it is through cultural expression that each goal will be considered and brought to life on canvas. Each piece will be thoughtfully created to highlight the actions that we may take together, individually and collectively, in order to ensure a more equitable future for our communities, our economies, and our environments.

One of the more evocative elements of culture is its ability to connect people from all different backgrounds in order to share and express ideas about the relationships among ourselves, our communities and our built and natural environments. Cultural exchanges can also help to build trust within and among diverse communities that sustain meaningful and productive social and economic activities, and it's our intention that this project will develop trust throughout its course.

We’re at a pivotal moment in our world, and Art for the Future captures the spirit of this time, our collective optimism for the future, and a few ideas of what that future might look like when it arrives. Each piece represents a shared commitment to a more sustainable future.

Patrons can claim stewardship of one or more goals, and will have the opportunity to connect directly with the artist to give shape to the artwork. Patrons will be encouraged to share their thoughts, ideas, and hopes for heritage conservation, art, and sustainable development, which will in turn be reflected on canvas.

Patrons will be able to track the art project as it progresses through regular communication updates, along with entertaining news, ideas and inspiration for action that can be taken in pursuit of the goals.

Each limited edition piece and print is signed by the artist, and comes with a certificate of authenticity and information about the initiative. The project will take place over the summer and fall of 2021, and patrons will receive their perks well ahead of Christmas.

The Backstory

This project is being undertaken by the staff at Heritage Connects, a small business that works to integrate heritage conservation and sustainable development. With respect for our shared global heritage, our interdisciplinary team works in the space where theory and practice, tradition and innovation converge in order to sustain connections among people and place.

This year, as part of our corporate social responsibility strategy, we challenged ourselves to ‘think outside the box’ and find new ways to support sustainable activities and connect people with important cultural issues...and presto—Art for the Future was born.

The artwork is an expression of the exchanges among the artist, patrons and the environment in which they are produced. Each piece is a careful balancing act between what is and what could be, and reflect the tensions between the strength and fragility inherent in our culture and environment. The art serves to translate policy into action and in doing so mediates the landscape between theory and practice, the realm of the ideal and the more pragmatic world. Each piece expresses hope and ambition: each traces a journey of the ideas that change our world, and the complex process of the sublimation of these ideas into the tangible and material. This is Art for the Future.

Art for Impact

Building creative capacity: We are planning to raise $50,000+. This funding will cover project expenses that include materials, shipping, and crowd-funding platform fees. Any profit over and above this will be used to support the evolution of Heritage Connects as it grows from a part-time idea into a full-time non-profit social enterprise. We have other conservation projects in the development stage that we're looking forward to sharing, and Art for the Future represents a step forward down this path.

The power of cultural exchange: Our patrons are co-drivers on this project! You have the opportunity to take stewardship of one or more of the sustainable development goals and directly shape the art that is produced.

Sustainable development on canvas: Patrons and backers will enjoy the fruits of artistic labours through a unique, one-of-a-kind limited edition original artwork that is suitable for framing. This could sit in a place of pride on your wall, and also makes for a meaningful  personal or CSR-friendly corporate gift.

Leveraging inspiration: the collectible postcards and sticker sets featuring each of the seventeen artworks can be used to help spread the word. Spark a conversation with your friends and family. Counter apathy with action and share your ideas about what a more sustainable future could look like, a story, or your favourite recipe. 

From ideas to action: The project supports SDGs 8, 11, 12 and 17. We'll use sustainable materials, and support local businesses and those with corporate social responsibility strategies that consider sustainable development through our activities. 

We thank you in advance for your support. On the off chance we don't reach our entire goal, we'll use the existing funds to continue the project with a more limited scope. Cultural expressions are resilient and persistent: Art for the Future embodies this spirit!

About the Artist

Nancy Oakley is a Canadian public historian, educator, and cultural heritage specialist. She has over ten years' experience working directly with communities and cultural organizations to help them build capacity by leveraging the power of culture, history and place. Her work integrates the conservation of natural and cultural heritage in order to sustain distinct cultural expressions, biodiversity, and economic prosperity. Her literary contributions and visual art have appeared in bookstores and gallery spaces across Canada. She is an active volunteer with culture and heritage organizations, and enjoys offering free* advice to industry leaders and decision-makers about the importance of conserving heritage.

Art for the Future: a Challenge and Opportunity

We've designed and led collaborative initiatives before. We also have over twenty years' experience creating artwork. What's new and exciting for us is to bring both of these activities together. We're excited to use a new way connect and collaborate with stakeholders that creates meaningful dialogue about policy. Artistically, the project represents a challenge to translate an exchange of perspectives through the medium of canvas and acrylic.  

While the current socio-economic conditions have made living and working a little more challenging these days, we see this as wonderful incentive to take on this initiative--if not now, then when? This project offers a unique opportunity to capture the spirit of the times as we re-consider and re-affirm our common global humanity.

We Appreciate Your Support

Patrons can support this initiative by supporting the creation of one or more original pieces. Patrons who back the production of original artwork at the $1,000 will have the opportunity to connect directly with the artist to help give shape to the art.

Backers who want to support this project can also purchase limited edition reproductions, collectible postcards and sticker sets, and will be included in our project updates.

    We're excited about this project and hope you are too--please share this campaign and help raise awareness of Art for the Future!

The artwork is an expression of the exchanges among the artist, patrons and the environment in which they are produced. Each piece is a careful balancing act between what is and what could be, and reflect the tensions between the strength and fragility inherent in our culture and environment. The art serves to translate policy into action and in doing so mediates the landscape between theory and practice, the realm of the ideal and the more pragmatic world. Each piece expresses hope and ambition: each traces a journey of the ideas that change our world, and the complex process of the sublimation of these ideas into the tangible and material. This is Art for the Future.
Art for Impact
Building creative capacity: We are planning to raise $50,000+. This funding will cover project expenses that include materials, shipping, and crowd-funding platform fees. Any profit over and above this will be used to support the evolution of Heritage Connects as it grows from a part-time idea into a full-time non-profit social enterprise. We have other conservation projects in the development stage that we're looking forward to sharing, and Art for the Future represents a step forward down this path.
The power of cultural exchange: Our patrons are co-drivers on this project! You have the opportunity to take stewardship of one or more of the sustainable development goals and directly shape the art that is produced.
Sustainable development on canvas: Patrons and backers will enjoy the fruits of artistic labours through a unique, one-of-a-kind limited edition original artwork that is suitable for framing. This could sit in a place of pride on your wall, and also makes for a meaningful  personal or CSR-friendly corporate gift.
Leveraging inspiration: the collectible postcards and sticker sets featuring each of the seventeen artworks can be used to help spread the word. Spark a conversation with your friends and family. Counter apathy with action and share your ideas about what a more sustainable future could look like, a story, or your favourite recipe. 
From ideas to action: The project supports SDGs 8, 11, 12 and 17. We'll use sustainable materials, and support local businesses and those with corporate social responsibility strategies that consider sustainable development through our activities. 
We thank you in advance for your support. On the off chance we don't reach our entire goal, we'll use the existing funds to continue the project with a more limited scope. Cultural expressions are resilient and persistent: Art for the Future embodies this spirit!
About the Artist
Nancy Oakley is a Canadian public historian, educator, and cultural heritage specialist. She has over ten years' experience working directly with communities and cultural organizations to help them build capacity by leveraging the power of culture, history and place. Her work integrates the conservation of natural and cultural heritage in order to sustain distinct cultural expressions, biodiversity, and economic prosperity. Her literary contributions and visual art have appeared in bookstores and gallery spaces across Canada. She is an active volunteer with culture and heritage organizations, and enjoys offering free* advice to industry leaders and decision-makers about the importance of conserving heritage.
Art for the Future: a Challenge and Opportunity
We've designed and led collaborative initiatives before. We also have over twenty years' experience creating artwork. What's new and exciting for us is to bring both of these activities together. We're excited to use a new way connect and collaborate with stakeholders that creates meaningful dialogue about policy. Artistically, the project represents a challenge to translate an exchange of perspectives through the medium of canvas and acrylic.  
While the current socio-economic conditions have made living and working a little more challenging these days, we see this as wonderful incentive to take on this initiative--if not now, then when? This project offers a unique opportunity to capture the spirit of the times as we re-consider and re-affirm our common global humanity.

We Appreciate Your Support
Patrons can support this initiative by supporting the creation of one or more original pieces. Patrons who back the production of original artwork at the $1,000 will have the opportunity to connect directly with the artist to help give shape to the art.
Backers who want to support this project can also purchase limited edition reproductions, collectible postcards and sticker sets, and will be included in our project updates.

We're excited about this project and hope you are too--please share this campaign and help raise awareness of Art for the Future!

story:
My Story:

Hello! My name is Sydney Bernard, I am 17 years old and I am a contortionist. 
Originally I am from Berkeley CA, but my mom and I moved to Los Angeles about 3 years ago to escape an abusive household. The move was really difficult for me to adjust to. I struggled making friends in all my new schools, and constantly worried for my family that I had to leave behind. Things were seeming pretty grim... And thats when I happened to stumbled upon Kinetic Theory Theatre, a circus school for aspiring artists. From the moment I entered Kinetic Theory I knew it was the light at the end of the tunnel. 
As a former gymnast, I had always been interested in circus-specifically contortion, however my coaches and peers had often told me I would not be able to pursue it because I was not born naturally flexible. Much to my suprise, my coaches at Kinetic Theory were all extremely supportive and so I began training 7hrs a week. 

It wasn't until my first performance at KT where I discovered my passion for the stage. The feeling I get when I'm performing is immeasurable. I feel so free and happy. Discovering circus and performance was the best thing that has ever happened to me. It is not only a positive outlet for me to express myself, but it has been a way for me to overcome things that I have been through and grow as a person. I cannot change my unfortunate past, but I can work to sculpt a bright and successful future for myself.

After a while, I was invited to join Kinetic Theory's Pre-Professional Troupe. The troupe trains 9hrs a week, primarily focusing on their main discipline, but also working on acrobatics, dance, and theatre. They perform three full length shows a year, and also perform at gigs and events around Los Angeles. I felt so lucky to be invited into such an incredible program with such talented people. My troupe felt like the happy loving family I had never had. I could feel safe with them.

It was around this time that I started to become close with my coach, and Kinetic Theory's owner/director Stephanie Abrams. When I first met her I had no idea what a huge part of my life she'd become. I am so grateful I met her. She is so generous and hardworking, and she continues to be an inspiration for me each day.

Stephanie accepted me as her apprentice. I now have a scholarship to train 25hours a week. I perform gigs around Los Angeles and at the end of this year I plan on launching my professional career. 

My new act that I have developed is a performance art piece. I have combined my passion for art and painting with my passion for contortion and performance. As I continue to get more advanced, more oppurtunities are arising for me. This summer my troupe will be travelling to China for a Circus Cultural Exchange. We will be training and performing for 2weeks at several circus schools all over the country. Then in January, I am auditioning for the annual Cirque De Demain festival in Paris, France. My mentor and I have decided, that regardless of if I am accepted into the festival or not, we will still go to France to promote my new act. I am so grateful for these wonderful opportunities that have opened up for me, however the one thing that's holding me back from pursuing them is my current financial situation. Unfortunatley my mom and I are barely making ends meet at home, and could never be able to pay for me to follow my dream.
I have never been down an easy road, I have always had to work hard for the things I've wanted, but now the situation is simply beyond my control. I worry that these two incredible opportunities will only come once in my life time. Please help me follow my dreams. I appreciate any contribution, and am so grateful for the generous people in this world who will be able to help me.
Thank you for listening to my story.



The Funding I Need:

I am currently working as a coach at Kinetic Theory to pay for a portion of my training, but between 25hours a week of training, and 6hours a week of coaching, and maintaining my grades in online high school, I simply just do not have the time or energy for a second job. In order to be able to go perform in China and France I will need to raise around $5,000.

- The cultural exchange in China costs $3,200. That includes flights, hotels, transportation between cities, and meals.

- It will cost $1,500 for a plane ticket to Paris. Once I've arrived in the city I will be able to stay with a family friend.

All funds raised from this campaign will go to helping me pursue my career as a professional contortionist.

I have created some unique perks for those who donate! Some of which include signed photos, personalized letters, photos, and postcards from my travels, and your own personal contortion thank you video!

 

 

What It Means To Me:

 

Circus means the world to me. There is not a day that goes by where I am not thinking of the next step in my training, or the next trick I will work towards. I am beyond dedicated to being the best I can possibly be and am always striving towards mastery. 

Three years ago becoming a circus preformer was merely a distant dream of mine, and now I can hardly believe how real it has become. I feel so honoured and proud to be able to represent Kinetic Theory and it's high standards and ideals in my work.

The chance to go on these trips could make my career. It could mean I will be able to sign a contract and go on tour with a big name circus troupe, like Cirque Du Soleil. I cannot even begin to describe the happiness circus brings me, and the happiness you will bring me by helping fund my campaign, Thank you so much! I can't say it enough- Thank you, thank you, thank you!

 

Anything Helps!

 

Trust me, I understand not everyone has cash to spare. You can help by sharing this page! Help me get my story out and get people involved. Share this page on your Facebook, Twitter, etc. 
Thank You so much everyone!
 
For photos of my work, Check out these links!
https://www.facebook.com/pages/Sydney-Bernard-Contortion/429838303774612

 

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oNtRrGBLPtQ&list=UU0Lo17HwWgDuE7jIS1_xvOQ&feature=player_embedded

http://kinetictheorytheatre.com/gallery.html

story:
Background and Beginnings

I have spent a lot of time in the southern Appalachian region over the last 40 years and it is where my daughter, Candy, grew up. Candy passed away on July 5,2013 at the age of 39 and her passing has made me reflect on my life goals. More importantly, how we tend to set aside our goals while we do all the things that are necessary to raise our families and provide for them. This project will achieve one of my goals in life, but is also a tribute to Candy and the beauty that surrounded her through out her life.

The Appalachian Mountains are the oldest mountain range in North America and they hold more mystery than anywhere I have ever been. The majestic views from the peaks and the breathtaking chill of the waterfalls that dot the landscape fill the heart and soul with a sense of wonder that is overwhelming! 


"Mist On The Mountains, Southern Appalachians" is a compilation of fine art images to be printed as a coffee table book. Many of the images for this book have already been produced and the remainder will be shot over the course of the next 90 days. 

 The death of my daughter showed me in no uncertain terms that we are not promised tomorrow, next week or next year. I will be 60 at the end of this year and the time has come for me to make this dream happen.

My plan includes the printing of, at least, 100 copies of the book. Of course, going over the original funding goal will increase the number of books we can produce. 

Making The Commitment

At the end of August 2014, I closed my business and ended a nearly 4 decades long career in tattooing. I did this as a leap of faith and to force myself to devote 100% effort to making this project come to fruition. Did I make the right call? I think so. This is where my heart has led me and it is the path I have chosen to follow. I would love for you to share this journey with me as we explore the beauty of the lands and landmarks of the Southern Appalachian Mountains!


    Risks & Challenges

    Travel expenses are the biggest challenge in the completion of the project. The southern portion of the Appalachian Mountains extend from southern Maryland all the way down into South Carolina. It's a lot of space to cover. Ideally, I would like to acquire a travel trailer to save on expenses like hotels, food, and maintaining a space to use my computer for editing images. I have been working on some trade deals to that end. 

    Weather is also always a consideration when it comes to outdoor photography, however, I do own an umbrella and I don't believe I would melt if I got wet. Protecting the cameras and lenses is first priority in inclement weather.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help. Please, pass the word to all your friends and contacts. The more people that know of this project, the more likely we can reach or, even, exceed our goals. I will even provide a pre-written outline of the project that can be copied and pasted to your emails and social media posts on my blog at www.jmhillphoto.com/blog.

story:
Three photographers are traveling to Paris/London and want to send you a self-printed postcard capturing the beauty of each place.

***THIS WILL MAINLY FUND THE PRODUCTION OF POSTCARDS AND SOME UNFORESEEN TRAVEL EVENTS   -- NOT OUR PLANE TICKET OR HOTELS! WE'VE ALREADY SAVED UP!

I will be shooting a ton of pictures along the way from Paris to London and I'd love to share all the things I encounter and experience along the way with as many people as possible.

I will be traveling with two of my closest friends, Abid and Shahmir. We created an Instagram (postcardsgoingsomewhere) that will allow you to see all of our photo updates and our previous travel pictures. We created this postcard project in response to everyone who wished they could come along. Our hope is that this will allow you to feel as if you've taken part in this special journey with us!

All the postcards will be produced and sent as soon as we get back to the United States. We'll take a picture of something decidedly beautiful, post them onto our Instagram, and either send you a random print or send you a selected one of your choice. 

We've been saving up and planning for this trip -- we're ready to go October 3rd no matter what. We're doing this campaign to cover the cost of a printing, paper, ink, and postage. It breaks down to $2 a postcard for a standard size. 

Check out our Instagram at Postcards Going Somewhere  and don't forget to follow us for the most current updates on our journey. 

Here is what the postcards will look like. 

*** If the project isn't funded, you will still receive the most popular postcard size. However, the postcard picture might be selected at random or we will take a poll and send the most popular picture.

story:
Short Summary

Hi! My name is Sunaina Mahendrakar and my goal is to raise funds for the construction of an elderly home in Aurangabad, India.

Last October, my grandfather in India passed away. My grandmother was devastated having lost her life partner and having to face the world alone. Fortunately, we found a home for her with my aunt in Aurangabad. Then, I realized not every elder in India was fortunate enough to have had a place to go like my grandmother. Moreover, many elders are disregarded and therefore left alone to take care of themselves.

What We Need

There is an elderly home that my aunt is building and they are desperately in need of money to fund its construction and future expenses.As a first step, I asked my friends to donate toward this elderly home instead of bring presents for my 16th Birthday. Thank you to all my friends who generously contributed toward this cause!!! (listed below):

Shefali Mangtani, Anish Iyengar, Sumanya Kumar, Shreya Vijay, Srilekha Vangavolu, Shrvani Balaji, Simren Bhogal, Dominique Lui, Aditi Srinivasan, Siddarth Ganguri, Srivatsan Senthilkumar, Kuhu Wadhwa, and Ronny Angeles.

However, I was not able to raise enough money. Please help me to reach my goal of $500 to help the less fortunate elderly in India. 

The Impact

Reaching the $500 mark will provide the elderly home in construction and financial security. Together, we can make sure no elder in Aurangabad is forgotten by providing a home where they will receive love and care for the rest of their lives.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about this campaign so we can get as many people to help as we can!

story:
WHY DOES ANCIENT KNOWLEDGE MATTER IN THE MODERN WORLD?*

THE BEGINNING WAS THE END is an exhibition that translates traditional knowledge from the Indonesian island of Java and how it intersects with contemporary ideas about nature and reality. By applying my own original research to my art practice, I am experimenting with how this dying knowledge might be brought to the West by new media, and how it may innovate that same technology. *(Please see Wade Davis at The Long Now Foundation, 01.13.2010.)


WHAT BEGAN â€˜THE BEGINNINGâ€™?

I started my independent research in Java in 2008. Over four months of talking with a dalang (shadowpuppet master) about things like the structure of human consciousness, animism, and devices that express time in terms of infinite, cyclical patterns of energies, I saw extraordinary relationships to cognitive science, theoretical physics, and science fiction. In 2009, I was awarded a Fulbright Fellowship to research them by the US Department of State.


 

For the next year, I explored traditional tools for navigating alternate dimensions of reality. I worked with Javanese philosophy professors, with Ki Sutino Hardono Carito, the oldest living dukun (shaman) in Central Java, and experienced the rituals I studied first hand. I made diagrams of these complex ideas, and designed them in the style of Indonesian educational posters to imagine traditional knowledge being taught in State classrooms (where, as an intervention, this project will actually install them). And I began to hear that some of this research has never been done before.



What's most important to me is that people experience these ideas through feeling. Over a six-month residency, I collaborated with pioneering artists, like the new media lab House Of Natural Fiber, to make models of them in videosculpture and live-processed sound.

 





  These pieces represent 3-dimensional chunks erased from our reality, revealing the alternate forces and energies present in the same time and space we occupy. In 2010, THE BEGINNING WAS THE END opened at Cemeti Art House; since then it's featured in cellsbutton#04, #05, Video Vortex #7, and led to an invitation to present at UC Santa Barbaraâ€™s College of Creative Studies. After a full year of shipping problems, I recently went back to Java on a four-day trip to rescue this now-damaged work. This Spring at Kala Art Institute, Iâ€™ll finally be able to complete its prints, sound, videosculptures, and annotated book, A Field Guide To Hybrid Reality, over a 3-month residency.    

But I canâ€™t do it without your help!


WHAT WILL YOUR GENEROUS DOLLARS SUPPORT?

THE BEGINNING WAS THE END is already 75% complete, but I need your support to see it through. I need to raise a minimum of $15,000 to help cover:

Â·       costs associated with 3-month artist residency at Kala Art Institute, including studio fees

Â·       video pre- and post-production costs, including mapping video to 3D sculptures and installation

Â·       surround sound design, production, and installation

Â·       digital printing of educational posters, including materials and processing

Â·       language translation services and shipping for Indonesia-bound posters

Â·       production of A Field Guide To Hybrid Reality, an annotated companion to the posters

Â·       development of web-based content for upcoming exhibitions and symposia, and beyond

Â·       refinishing of damaged polyester resin sculptures


 

What's great is that I'm starting this campaign having already met 1/3 of my goal, so if 200 people contribute $50, Iâ€™ll have all the funds I need. But even the smallest donation is important, and thanks to my fiscal sponsor, Fractured Atlas, any amount is TAX DEDUCTIBLE.


In return, some singular rewards that reflect the spirit and culture of Java will be yours. More details about the awards and their makers will be provided in my regular updates. Please help spread the word by emailing this video, joining me on Facebook, and talking to people the old-fashioned way about this important research, at the crossroads of several disciplines.


If we exceed our goal, my team and I can complete this work sooner, and in time for the International Symposium of Electronic Arts (ISEA), the ZER01 symposium, and Ars Electronica, all taking place in summer, 2012.


I sincerely appreciate your support, and I'm excited to see how together we can contribute to how we know our world, how we know ourselves, and what art can be. Thank you!

 

Allison Leigh Holt and â€œThe Beginning Was The Endâ€ team

www.oillyoowen.com

The Oilly Oowen Netweb

The Beginning Was The End's Facebook Page

The OOsphere

CAN I CONTRIBUTE MORE THAN ONCE?

Absolutely! Click the 'AMOUNTâ€™ and â€˜CONTRIBUTE NOWâ€™ boxes located in green at the top right hand of this page and you will be taken to the Perks and Contributions page. You can come back as often as you like.

 

CAN I CONTRIBUTE INTERNATIONALLY?

Indeed you can! Just follow the steps above and go to â€˜STEP 4: PAYMENTâ€™ and â€˜SELECT CREDIT CARDâ€™ to enter your country details. If it gives you any static please let us know and we will gladly assist.
story_txt:
WHY DOES ANCIENT KNOWLEDGE MATTER IN THE MODERN WORLD?*


THE
BEGINNING WAS THE END is an exhibition that translates traditional knowledge
from the Indonesian island of Java and how it intersects with contemporary
ideas about nature and reality. By applying my own original research to my art
practice, I am experimenting with how this dying knowledge might be brought to
the West by new media, and how it may innovate that same technology. *(Please see Wade Davis at The Long Now Foundation, 01.13.2010.)


WHAT BEGAN â€˜THE BEGINNINGâ€™?


I
started my independent research in Java in 2008. Over four months of talking
with a dalang (shadowpuppet master)
about things like the structure of human consciousness, animism, and devices
that express time in terms of infinite, cyclical patterns of energies, I saw
extraordinary relationships to cognitive science, theoretical physics, and science
fiction. In 2009, I was awarded a Fulbright Fellowship to
research them by the US Department of State. 

 


For
the next year, I explored traditional tools for navigating alternate dimensions
of reality. I worked with Javanese philosophy professors, with Ki Sutino
Hardono Carito, the oldest living dukun
(shaman) in Central Java, and experienced the rituals I studied first hand. I
made diagrams of these complex ideas, and designed them in the style of
Indonesian educational posters to imagine traditional knowledge being taught in
State
classrooms (where, as an intervention, this project will actually
install them). And I began to hear that some of this research has never been done before. 




What's
most important to me is that people experience these ideas through feeling.
Over a six-month residency, I collaborated with pioneering artists, like the new media lab House Of Natural Fiber, to make models of them in videosculpture and live-processed
sound.  
















 










These pieces represent 3-dimensional chunks erased
from our reality, revealing the alternate forces and energies present in the
same time and space we occupy. In 2010, THE BEGINNING WAS THE END opened at Cemeti Art House; since then it's featured in cellsbutton#04, #05, Video Vortex #7, and led to an invitation to present
at UC Santa
Barbaraâ€™s College of Creative Studies. After a full year of shipping
problems, I recently went back to Java on a four-day trip to rescue this
now-damaged work. This Spring at Kala
Art Institute, Iâ€™ll finally be able to complete its prints,
sound, videosculptures, and annotated book, A Field Guide To Hybrid Reality,
over a 3-month residency.  


  

 
But I canâ€™t do it without your help!


WHAT WILL YOUR GENEROUS DOLLARS SUPPORT?

THE
BEGINNING WAS THE END is already 75% complete, but I need your support to see
it through. I need to raise a minimum of
$15,000 to help cover:
Â·       costs
associated with 3-month artist residency at Kala Art Institute, including
studio fees 
Â·       video
pre- and post-production costs, including mapping video to 3D sculptures and
installation
Â·       surround
sound design, production, and installation
Â·       digital
printing of educational posters, including materials and processing
Â·       language
translation services and shipping for Indonesia-bound posters
Â·       production
of A Field Guide To Hybrid Reality, an annotated companion to the
posters
Â·       development
of web-based content for upcoming exhibitions and symposia, and beyond
Â·       refinishing
of damaged polyester resin sculptures













 











What's
great is that I'm starting this
campaign having already met 1/3 of my goal, so if 200 people contribute
$50, Iâ€™ll have all the funds I need. But even the smallest donation is
important, and thanks to my fiscal sponsor, Fractured Atlas, any
amount is TAX DEDUCTIBLE. 


In return, some singular rewards that reflect the spirit and
culture of Java will be yours. More details about the awards and their makers
will be provided in my regular updates. Please help spread the word by emailing
this video, joining me on Facebook, and
talking to people the old-fashioned way about this important research, at the
crossroads of several disciplines.

If we exceed our goal, my team and I can complete this work sooner,
and in time for the International Symposium of Electronic Arts (ISEA), the ZER01 symposium, and
Ars Electronica, all taking
place in summer, 2012. 


I
sincerely appreciate your support, and I'm excited to see how together we can
contribute to how we know our world, how we know ourselves, and what art can
be. Thank you!
 
Allison
Leigh Holt and â€œThe Beginning Was The Endâ€ team

The Oilly Oowen Netweb

Was The End's Facebook Page
The OOsphere

INTERNATIONALLY?

story:
100 Bedrooms

For the past year I have been photographing portraits of people in one of the most personal spaces they occupy.

My goal has been to reach 100 portraits, currently up to 70, I have 30 to go. For each portrait I shoot a roll of film, and each will be hand printed on traditional fibre based photographic paper as a one off.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

I need a little help with the costs of the  the exhibition. Any funds raised will go to the production of the prints and the exhibition space.

 
 
 
***UPDATE***
100 portraits have now been completed.
With the exhibition due to open on May 17th, printing begins in the next two weeks.

NEW SECRET PERK NOW AVAILABLE! Wheat paste poster pack!! See link below!

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/no-apologies-urban-art-tour--2/x/13198923?secret_perk_token=6a2f3803



Arrex Skulls, Voxx Romana and Mad One will be traveling over the pond to London to pop-up a small group art exhibition. With that being said, you know why we are all here... The three Portland artists have teamed up and designed some great handmade perks for YOU our friends, fans,and supporters to obtain while supporting our mission. So now is your chance to support our cause and get your hands on some super rare limited edition items that have only been created for this purpose and will never be duplicated! Once these items are gone, thats it! 

So now is your chance, there's something for everyone's budget! 

Check it out and spread the word! 

Donators to our fundraiser will receive a number of handmade items by Voxx Romana,Mad One and Arrex including sticker packs, tee shirts, posters, wood cutouts, original artwork, uncut sticker sheets and much MORE!...


Kiss cut screen printed vinyl sticker sheets

Arrex, Mad One and Voxx Romana Collab and friends Sticker Packs  $20.00


4 Hand printed uncut sticker sheets signed by the artists $50.00


Wood cut outs by Mad One $80.00


Wood cut outs by Arrex Skulls $80.00

Wood cut by Voxx Romana $80.00


Collaborative T-Shirt Design and Sticker Pack Combo $50.00

Please e-mail us your size of t-shirt or state your size when donating.



Giclee Print signed and numbered by Artists. $100.00

One of a kind notebooks made on our trip. $200.00

Ying and yang canvas set collab by Arrex,Voxx and Mad One  $95.00


**Some of the bigger priced items include collaborative murals (locally) $1000.00

 OR a sticker printing tutorial in Rx’s print studio with all three artists and lunch included your designs printed on vinyl or garment, YOU pick!   $1000.00

story:
Help Fund an Artistic Project!

As an independent artist, the ability to travel to and sell at conventions is vital to my livelihood.  You can help me with this years trip, and get cool glance-art merchandise before anybody else!  All the money will go into producing cool artwork, and the profits from any unsold merch will go towards the next project.

What We Need & What You Get

To get it rolling Glance needs funds for:

  • printing charms from a laser cutting company
  • ordering bags and apparel from a textile printing company
  • posters and other paper products from a print shop
And of course in return, you will get early access to rewards featuring all of these things.
Rewards:  Tales Duos

These charm necklaces will connect to either side with chain (non-allergic metal) with three sparkling bead drops.  Each features two characters from the Tales series.  More characters will appear based on response and demand!
 

(Rita & Estelle)
Sorey & Mikleo clear double-sided charm
A couple of nerds!  These charms come on your choice of keychain or cell phone strap, and are double-sided.



Risks & Challenges

The essential risk in production is product lost in the mail, theft, and other loss issues which impact the calculated base cost.  That is why I charge a margin on my items.

story:
Hello everyone,

For the past year I have been vigorously focusing on moving forward and elevating my career as a visual artist. I have been engaging with my work in new and profound ways both aesthetically and intellectually and I am incredibly excited as to where this is leading me. My daily routine balances the production of this new work with a lot of time writing residency and grant applications, art show proposals, and entering art prize competitions. I dedicate a lot of time to working, experimenting and writing in my sketchbook on a daily basis as well. If I am at the grocery store where I stock shelves and tell people where mayonnaise "lives" - I have a smaller, pocket sized sketchbook that I am always quickly scribbling notes and drawings into when I think the boss is not looking. I always have my craft or new ideas on my mind in some form - and if you know me well at all (or know anyone, really, who has no problem unabashedly labeling themselves an artist), then you know this isn’t just a career for me but rather it makes up a large portion of who I am as a person.

That said, I am happy to announce, after a lot of hard work this past year, I have been accepted into the NES Artist Residency program in a place called Skagaströnd, Iceland. This is a three month residency which will begin later this year. I will live and work in the small northern commune of Skagaströnd, creating a whole new body of work while meeting and interacting with some great new creative thinking people. I will have a home and a studio space, be giving public artist talks, mentoring high-school kids and showing my work to my peers and the local community in multiple exhibition settings. I am very humbled and thankful for this opportunity and it is certainly something that will propel my career forward, open doors and ultimately lead to more great possibilities for me.

However, this is not something that rewards me monetarily. In fact, it’s the opposite. I have to put out a lot of cash to make this happen. Fortunately, I live in place where there are grants and funding out there for artists like myself. I have already begun applying for as many of the grants that I am eligible for - and I am somewhat confident I will be able to convince some of these fine people to help me pay for this.

The reason I have created this crowdfunding profile is to raise money for the required deposit needed to secure my spot with the residency. The deposit is the first months fee and totals to about 1150 Canadian dollars (or 93,942 Icelandic krona). It is due to be payed within one month of my acceptance letter (which I received yesterday) and if I am unable to secure money for and pay this deposit within this approximate thirty day time-frame, I will not be able to accept my placement. Not only did I not completely anticipate being accepted into this program (lately, I have been viewing these applications as an exercise in dealing with rejection, heh) I also did not expect the news to come so quickly after applying. So, my goal is to sell quality prints of my work at $25 a piece through this funding page. There is another tier featuring a hand painted portrait option, in case you have some nice bonus money just burning a hole in your pocket. But, if I sell only forty prints, I can make up the majority of the money I require.

Most likely if you are reading this, you have probably supported me in the past in some form or another. Maybe it was something as small as shooting me a like or comment on a piece of art I shared on social media, or maybe you attended a weird puppet show I put on, or commissioned me to draw your cat ...or bought a print. Whatever it was, I am very grateful for it and for your support now.

story:
Chi-TEK == Women + Technology + Art


Workshops + Showcase + Tea party!


Chi-TEK combines Art, Technology and Tea in an exciting new showcase of technologically-modified teapots, by 20 leading women artists and designers working in computer and new media arts today.

If you love art, technology and tea, lend your support today.



Chi-TEK urgently needs your help to bring to fruition: techie tea related workshops for women, an amazing showcase of tea pots, and a giant celebration tea party in the V&A garden which you are all invited to!

Women working in the arts and technology are largely underrepresented. By showing your support for Chi-TEK, you will be contributing to the campaign to highlight women's serious contribution to technology and computer arts.

Workshops

With your help, MzTEK hopes to host up to 4 subsidised Chi-TEK workshops this autumn at SPACE, in Hackney and locations around London. We have already run a fantastic “Shiver My Teacups’” workshop. Teacups from this workshop will also be on display as part of the showcase.

   

Showcase

The modified tea pots showcase will run throughout September to November at the Victoria & Albert Museum, Sackler Centre, in London, England.

Tea Party

In a fantastic celebration, we will host a giant tea party in the V&A garden, which will take part in the London Design Week Digital Weekend on the weekend of 24 & 25th September.

We have the space. We have the artists. Now we need the funding. Help make this happen!


THE IMPACT

Women are massively underrepresented in the field of technology, science, and computer science.

Chi-TEK aims to highlight, and especially to the next generation of women artist, techies and tinkerers, what innovative areas of technology women are exploring.

On a global scale it is imperative that women are not left behind technological advancements. Social exclusion and exploitation occurs if people lack the language and confidence to navigate technology, and women are by far the biggest marginalised group in this field.

Let’s not forget that the first computer programme was written by Ada Lovelace, and the first compiler was written by Grace Hopper. So anyone believing that women just don’t have the skills is simply wrong!

Help us create the coverage, recognition and exposure women deserve.

OUR STORY

MzTEK provides opportunities for women to creatively explore and expand their experience of working with technology.  We are a not-for-profit organisation whose aims are to provide accessible training to women, to promote women technology artists, and to create a network of women techie artists.

MzTEK: women artists, techies and tinkerers from MAT_OPEN on Vimeo.



You can find more about our workshops at www.mztek.org.

WHAT WE NEED

The money raised will go towards:

    Chi-TEK workshops for women and girls.
    The commission of new work by internationally acclaimed and emerging artists
    Producing the Chi-TEK showcase and Tea Party at the V&A Museum, with a bang!
    Video production and documentation of the Chi-TEK project.
    Publicity material for all Chi-TEK projects

If we reach our campaign goals, we will successfully deliver Chi-TEK at V&A this September to November, with all the bells and whistles that it deserves.  Any extra funds will allow us to host further workshops as part of the Chi-TEK workshop series. We deeply appreciate your contribution and will strive to provide the best service possible.

WHAT YOU GET

Firstly, you get the satisfaction of helping make Chi-TEK a fantastic success, and joining in the celebration of women’s accomplishments in art and technology.

Every contributor will be thanked on the MzTEK Chi-TEK contributors page (unless submitted as anonymous) and depending on the level of your contribution you will receive...
Limited addition Chi-TEK badges, tea towel and mug!
We also have some sugru (the stuff that helps you hack things better) to give away with your donation, thanks to the kind folks at sugru :) See the "sugru Special" on the right. 

GOODIES!


      

Choose your perks on the right =>

If you or your company would like to become a sponsor of the Chi-TEK project, and have your logo on Chi-TEK print materials and website, please get in touch with us at info@mztek.org

VISIT Chi-TEK

Find out more about Chi-TEK and the artists involved at www.mztek.org/chi-tek
Come and join in the tea party on 24th and 25th September 2011
Visit the Showcase: September 7th - November 30th
V&A, Sackler Centre, Cromwell Road, London SW7 2RL

To find out more about MzTEK's projects visit www.mztek.org

Thank you for your generous support!

Other ways you can help:

Spread the word!
Women, if you would like to help us throughout the project with some of your time, we would love to hear from you. Contact us at info@mztek.org

story:
Our Story

I've been an independent artist, illustrator and designer since 2006. My Custom Tarot Deck series began way back in 2008, it's seen a lot of revisions but now it's finally finished! Of course, a full Tarot Deck is 78 Cards, so at this stage I've designed the most important cards - the Major Arcana - which you can do simple, general readings with. I'd love to release each suit separately in the future and offer a handmade, stitched bag to store the full deck.

The Major Arcana deck features vintage and retro digital collage artworks which is my trademark artistic style. I put a lot of research into each card, to accurately represent the meanings and symbolism of each - just about every detail is there for a reason and not just to look pretty!


The Impact

I've had a lot of interest in the cards ever since I first started. People have been asking when the set will be available to buy - many want to buy a set as a gift for their Mum! The cards have definitely aroused the strongest emotional response of all my artwork and it would be a shame not to see them produced!

I have no other funding sources, so if I don't reach my target amount then I'll have to hussle myself to friends and family to invest the remaining amount. I'm determined to get this project off the ground one way or another, but without support I may have to shelve the project indefinitely.


What We Need & What You Get

CLICK THE UPDATES TAB TO GET THE LATEST INFO - THINGS HAVE CHANGED!

Printing, production and shipping costs are at the $1000 mark, give or take. It's a race against time to get these done in time for Christmas! Depending on funds raised I can get 100 decks printed or 500 - it all comes down to different printers. 

Donations of $30 or more will receive their own Tarot Deck with free shipping.

Donations of $100 or more will receive their own Tarot Deck with free shipping PLUS a choice between:

a) 2 x Limited Edition Signed Prints, OR

b) 1 x custom stitchy artwork.


Other Ways You Can Help

Can't afford to donate today? I know that feeling! Perhaps you'd consider sharing a link on Facebook or Twitter to help spread the word? Thanks for considering!
story_txt:
Our Story
I've been an independent artist, illustrator and designer since 2006. My Custom Tarot Deck series began way back in 2008, it's seen a lot of revisions but now it's finally finished! Of course, a full Tarot Deck is 78 Cards, so at this stage I've designed the most important cards - the Major Arcana - which you can do simple, general readings with. I'd love to release each suit separately in the future and offer a handmade, stitched bag to store the full deck.
The Major Arcana deck features vintage and retro digital collage artworks which is my trademark artistic style. I put a lot of research into each card, to accurately represent the meanings and symbolism of each - just about every detail is there for a reason and not just to look pretty!


The Impact
I've had a lot of interest in the cards ever since I first started. People have been asking when the set will be available to buy - many want to buy a set as a gift for their Mum! The cards have definitely aroused the strongest emotional response of all my artwork and it would be a shame not to see them produced! 
I have no other funding sources, so if I don't reach my target amount
 then I'll have to hussle myself to friends and family to invest the 
remaining amount. I'm determined to get this project off the ground one 
way or another, but without support I may have to shelve the project indefinitely.


What We Need & What You Get
CLICK THE UPDATES TAB TO GET THE LATEST INFO - THINGS HAVE CHANGED!
Printing, production and shipping costs are at the $1000 mark, give or take. It's a race against time to get these done in time for Christmas! Depending on funds raised I can get 100 decks printed or 500 - it all comes down to different printers. 
Donations of $30 or more will receive their own Tarot Deck with free shipping.
Donations of $100 or more will receive their own Tarot Deck with free shipping PLUS a choice between:
a) 2 x Limited Edition Signed Prints, OR
b) 1 x custom stitchy artwork.


Other Ways You Can Help

Can't afford to donate today? I know that feeling! Perhaps you'd consider sharing a link on Facebook or Twitter to help spread the word? Thanks for considering!

story:
Summary

We want to raise $30,000 in 30 days, and you can help!

Raising $30,000 by November 30 will allow us to continue our wonderful theater, music, and arts programs. For 47 years we have provided fine arts exhibitions and extraordinary theater and music performances to all of East Hawaii. We want to continue the tradition of providing art exhibits, low cost arts performances and arts education to our community, but IT TAKES YOU TO SUPPORT OUR EFFORTS!

Give the gift of ART to Hilo - Make a contribution to the East Hawai`i Cultural Council, and Hawai`i Museum of Contemporary Art, and receive a mahalo makana of art - which you can keep for yourself OR get a jump on holiday gift giving!

By making a contribution to EHCC/HMOCA you are insuring that our community continues to receive the benefits of participation in the arts and arts education. Every contributor will receive a surprise gift that you or a loved one will treasure.

The East Hawai`i Cultural Council has been a huge part of Hilo's culture and arts scene for 47 years. That's a LOT of dedication on the part of the many volunteers like you who have made EHCC the center for arts and culture. Donations by people like YOU make all the difference! So, we thank you for all your kokua over the years, and look forward to your continued support.

As you know federal, state and county funding is now greatly reduced and we depend on public support to make our programs successful. EHCC/HMOCA is a private arts organization run by volunteers. All of the funds we receive go into programs. We have no paid staff.

Aloha!

My name is Lourdan Kimbrell, President of the EHCC Board of Directors and acting Director of the Hawaii Museum of Contemporary Art. I’ve been an arts educator for over 30 years in the San Francisco Bay Area teaching at California College of Art, Sonoma State University, and San Francisco Art Institute among other arts facilities. As an arts administrator instrumental in establishing non for profit arts centers in San Francisco Area, I’m proud to be able to bring my expertise to the Hawaii Museum of Contemporary Art as I believe that this community deserves a first rate arts and cultural institution. Through my efforts we have been accepted by the Alliance of American Museums for their assessment and accreditation program which will enable us to provide professionally guided programs and events in Hilo.

What We've Done

A lot is happening to the old East Hawaii Cultural Center which has a new name, Hawaii Museum of Contemporary Art ~ a new organization, a new mission and a new face. We are undergoing a lot of renovations to the buildings at our downtown Hilo site. We are working on a $50,000 window replacement and restoration project through a grant from Historic Hawaii Foundation.

The buildings on our site, once the Central Police Offices, Municipal Court and temporary holding jail, are on the National Register of Historic Places, In addition to the window renovations we are currently planning:

  • New and improved classroom spaces with upgraded lighting.

  • New rehearsal space.

  • Artist in residence apartment

  • Certified kitchen

  • New gallery for photography exhibitions.

  • On site museum store featuring the best of the best of local art and handmade

  • womens accessories and jewelry.

  • Plus a new Lanai Coffee Bar for your enjoyment.

We/re also developing new exciting classes for keiki, students, adults and retired folks so they have access to the highest level of extended arts education possible. We are engaging new professional teachers who are masters of their craft and we hope to develop a jewelry and textile design department. We, of course, will continue to provide excellent classes in photography, theater, voice training, yoga, martial arts, and much much more.

Take a look at www.EHCC.org.

Artists Contribute to the Community

We want to continue giving experienced artists a supportive venue, and to continue facilitating young artists who are just starting out.

For many Hawai`i Island artists who came of age in the past 50 years, EHCC helped them to get their start and to grow professionally. 

Our artists, in both performing and visual fields, are strong contributors to Hawai`i Island's economy, and are among the island's leaders in promoting environmental awareness. The arts bring awareness, and it is a renewable resource!

Help us to keep enriching our community by donating now.

If you would like to see the specifics of how we exercise stewardship over our funding, please contact the EHCC office at 961-9711 to schedule an appointment.

You are the Key to Our Success!

Through your generous contributions we can keep the dream alive. Remember, it was the East Hawaii Community who created this facility 47 years ago. It is your premier arts facility and we need your help.

What We Need

We began the year in the clear, and want to end it the same way. As we all know, the great programs we facilitate cost money. While all of the programs give value to our community, not all of them generate income. So we rely on donors like you to help us continue to serve Hilo and Hawai`i Island.

The first $30,000 we receive will be used for renovations of our buildings to ensure that they are handicapped accessible and that we have comfortable updated bathrooms.

Your contributions will provide us with the funds to:

  • Renovate our main exhibition rooms with new paint and repairs.

  • Build new updated walls throughout the galleries that will be bright, clean, and uniform bringing a new fresher appearance to the exhibitions.

  • Establish a new jewelry and textile design center attracting professional staff as well as enabling visiting artists and craftspeople a place to stay on site while they teach workshops.

  • Complete a certified kitchen which will allow us to bring in visiting chefs who will teach culinary arts. In addition, we will be able to hold weddings and receptions utilizing the wonderful space that we occupy and integrating Kalakaua Park. 

Should we fall short of the $30,000 in this funding drive, all of the funds received will go into our current renovations.

Community Impact

The impact of your donation will be felt throughout the community. EHCC/HMOCA is the meeting ground for all of East Hawaii. The facility is used for:

  • Community meetings - the League of Women Voters, the Downtown Hilo Improvement Association, for police meetings, civil defense and many more civic and social clubs.

  • This has been the place where local arts are showcased and has been for generations of people in the community. Many of our volunteers took art classes here as children.

  • We serve the handicapped and those people who have physical, emotional or mental challenges.

  • Our partnership with Orchid Isle Youth Orchestra allows students and Keiki a place to rehearse and perform.

  • We also are proud that we promote and exhibit Hawaiian cultural programs and exhibitions.

Our Mission

Our mission is to bring quality art and performance to Hilo and East Hawaii. We do so by encouraging local artists and craftspeople to exhibit their works. We also bring in programing and exhibitions from the international community as we believe that culture is not a static thing but benefits from an exchange of ideas.

In 47 years we have successfully showcased hundreds of individual artists, performers, musicians and teachers. We organized and sponsored the Big Island Music Festival for 24 years, advancing the music of the Hawaiian Islands.

Risks and Challenges

Our challenge is to re-envision ourselves for the 21st century. Times change and our community is changing, becoming more diverse and more connected to a global experience.

  • We must improve our facility, our classes, our ways of interacting with the community and the world.

  • Our aim is to transform our space into a destination where locals and visitors will want to come and enjoy performances, art, and to learn first-hand about many artistic ventures.

  • Our visitors will have the opportunity to shop for the best of local arts and crafts and will be able to sit on our beautiful lanai and sip coffee and enjoy the view of lovely Kalakaua Park.

  • Our upgraded facilities will welcome patrons to rent our meeting rooms for receptions and special events.

Without community support we won’t be able to offer all of these wonderful opportunities for art and culture to thrive in East Hawaii. Our volunteers work endless hours because they believe that this community should have a first rate art museum and museum school. They do this without pay because they love their community.

Please take the time to make a contribution that will make a difference.

Other Ways You Can Help

Besides supporting EHCC’s efforts to create a flourishing environment for the arts in Hilo, we also need volunteers who could contribute by helping with fund raising, publicity, web input, memberships, and other vital aspects of running the museum.

We at the Hawaii Museum of Contemporary Art welcome the public to come by and see first- hand what we are up to, talk with us and take a tour of the facility. Sharing with others in the community about the wonderful work that we do is how we engage with our patrons and others to build consensus about how we can better serve our constituents.

  • Ask your friends to spread the word - facebook, twitter, word of mouth, it all helps! You can start right here: https://www.facebook.com/HawaiiMOCA.

  • Volunteer as a docent, fund raiser, arts writer, or in other areas.

  • Participate in events and help spread the word about them.

Mahalo nui loa for your time and attention reading this all the way through. We know we can count on you for help.

Me ke aloha,
Lourdan Kimbrell,
East Hawai`i Cultural Council

story:
THE BUILD PROJECT

  • Metro's excited to be a part of this project, If you're far from a local shop or live in the Bay Area, we could use your help to raise $1000 in order to construct four or more spots in the Bay 

  • We have four unique spots that could use a little concrete/metal work in order to make em something amazing to skate! We'll publish photos of the before and after versions of the spots on our IG @metroskateboarding, it's our hope that with the build, more of our fellow skaters will be inspired to make the trip out to explore the East Bay. but before we can make that vision real, we need an estimated $1000 for concrete, rebar, forms and a handrail (the spot below is an actual sample of what we'd like to build with your help) 

  • DLX has sent $50 and a bucket out to 250 shops around the US, If you see one of the orange buckets at your local shop, please help your scene out by donating a few dollars. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need your help footing a $1000 materials bill in order to create four new street/trannie spots for all who venture through the East Bay to enjoy.
  •  We have Metro Stickers, Build Project T Shirts and Hand Screened Jim Thiebaud "Hanging Klansman" Posters for backers that help us meet our goal. 
  • If we come up short on our $1000 goal, we will build as much as the donations allow  ...then wait for the next time our wallets are flush n build the rest :) 

The Impact

  • A project like this is just the beginning! if you live in the bay area, theres a good chance you've enjoyed something we built, painted, bondo'd, clear coated, un skateblocked. If this project exceeds its goal, 100% of the excess will go to creating more spots for all to enjoy. Thanks DLX for lighting a fire with this one!

  • Dont have a dollar to your name? dont sweat it. Thanks for reading this! If you'd be willing, you can still help out by passing on this link/message on Instagram/Facebook/Youtube etc. we'd be very grateful for the support! To support future endeavors, and see how these projects come to life next month  please find us @metroskateboarding THANK YOU!

We have four unique spots that could use a little concrete/metal work in order to make em something amazing to skate! We'll publish photos of the before and after versions of the spots on our IG @metroskateboarding, it's our hope that with the build, more of our fellow skaters will be inspired to make the trip out to explore the East Bay. but before we can make that vision real, we need an estimated $1000 for concrete, rebar, forms and a handrail (the spot below is an actual sample of what we'd like to build with your help) 


DLX has sent $50 and a bucket out to 250 shops around the US, If you see one of the orange buckets at your local shop, please help your scene out by donating a few dollars.
