story:
About Us:

Changing Images Art Foundation is a 501(c)3 tax-exempt non-profit organization established in 1997 by Arlene RB Sullivan that provides "medicine for the soul" with its elaborate mural installation projects full of warm and vibrant colors that help brighten up institutional settings, allowing patients and caregivers to see pictures of hope and cheerfulness in what are commonly bleak surroundings, primarily nursing homes, hospitals, and treatment facilities.

Sullivan’s initial desire to form Changing Images came when her youngest child was hospitalized at two weeks of age and she spent two months in the intensive care unit with him.  A former art teacher, she was depressed that the only things that surrounded the patients in the unit were scary machinery, wires, tubing and beige, blank walls.  “After awhile, you start to adjust your breathing to the beeps.  The hospital itself and the medical staff were excellent but the atmosphere was not very cheerful or comforting,” says Sullivan. Her son is now happy and healthy. 

Arlene creates her projects with the help of volunteers from all walks of life: patients and hospital residential staff, doctors, corporate volunteers as well as known celebrities who have autographed her artwork. Each project is a process of healing as people of all different age groups work together to create murals and often revisit the work when they return, knowing they were part of creating something of beauty in a communal art activity. 

What We Need:

For our supplies:

120 large canvases, each acting as a piece of a larger mural. 

Black permanent markers for drawing and reworking the project in its final touches.

Non-toxic non-acrylic paints, both for the volunteers and patients to paint with as well as for subsequent touching up before the paintings are ready to be installed.

Varnish for touch-ups for when after painting is completed. 

What You Get: 

While staying overnight at the hospital with her younger son, Arlene was inspired to write and illustrate a childrens' book: The Journey of Hanna Heart.

Hanna Heart is carried off by the wind to faraway lands: a jungle, a glacier, and under the sea, never knowing where the wind will take her. In each place, based on the beautiful murals Arlene RB Sullivan has drawn, Hanna Heart sees beauty and makes the most of her new surroundings.

Our greater contributors will receive a butterfly kit with canvas butterflies hand drawn and cut by Arlene RB Sullivan and a kit with art supplies so that they can paint their own and beautify their own space at work or home.

The Impact

Changing Images has created many murals that have impacted the community. In 2008, in a collaboration with the Benedictine Academy of Elizabeth, NJ, we created a mural for the United Nations Offices asking them to speak out further against human trafficking.

We have also partnered with DAWN on three week-long canvas mural paintings, www.dawninfo.org, which advocates and promotes the integration and full inclusion of people with disabilities into the mainstream of American society.

We developed a special walk-in book project mural for the Dover, NJ, chapter of Head Start. 

In addition, we've created special projects with the Ronald McDonald House to benefit children with cancer, the Camelot House of Pennsylvania, working with Muhlenberg College, and dedicated murals to the children's reading room of the Montville Township Public Library in memory of former librarian Margaret Sidman. 

Jay Leno of Tonight Show fame autographed and dedicated one of our murals in memory of his parents to Lawrence General Hospital in his hometown of Andover, Massachusetts. 

Our artwork can be seen at hospitals throughout the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut tri-state area and in the last 16 years, we have built our artistic community to include the rest of the world. Our murals of healing can be seen in:

  • Australia
  • New Zealand
  • South Africa
  • Argentina
  • Peru
  • Scotland
  • England
  • Ireland
  • China
  • The Phillippines
  • Cayman Islands

Please make a donation today - every little bit goes a long way! Please spread the word to all your friends and neighbors! Check out our website at www.changingimages.org to find out more. Thank you for your time!

story:
Short Summary

The Bleachers is the most inclusive and interactive art car at Burning Man. It has played one big prank on itself over the years, and that prank was a joy to behold. Also, it was expensive...

In order to crank out one more 'hat-trick' year of jokes, we need your help with the costs of this beast.

If you can help us out, we'll be offering our undying gratitude and seats for the night of the burn! (Note, in spite of us screwing up the delivery dates on some of the perks, ALL of them are for Burning Man 2016, NOT 2017)

Here's the budget/cost breakdown:

Item $ Cost
Art Car/on-playa Insurance 2400
Vehicle Insurance 400
Storage 2015 1500
Storage 2016 1500
Gas (mostly return trip home) 300
Mechanical parts 450
Mechanical labor/repair/inspection - pre
 500
Sound/mics/speaker/electronics rental
 800
Expected repairs/tune-up to drive home 500
TOTAL $8350
We would love your help with covering $6000 of this, so we can gift thousands of Burners free rides and unlimited jokes on the Playa. Please help by providing a few bucks on here, and by sharing this campaign on "social media".

story:
Cas de figure

Nous sommes 21 étudiants en arts visuels et médiatiques investis dans un projet d'exposition qui marquera la fin de notre cursus à l'Université du Québec à Montréal. Depuis déjà plusieurs mois, nous nous sommes engagés dans une expérience collective d'échanges et de création qui culminera par une exposition hors des murs de l'école en avril 2015.

Nous souhaitons souligner l'importance du processus créatif d'un groupe. Pour ce faire, nous avons entrepris une série d'événements et d'actions artistiques. Au fil du temps, nous avons façonné notre identité de groupe autour de ces explorations. De façon à mettre en valeur l'ensemble de notre parcours, nous avons développé un système de nomenclature dans lequel chaque étape devient une «figure» portant un numéro selon son ordre d'apparition.

Il existe peu de programmes de subventions pour aider les étudiants de premier cycle à poursuivre leurs recherches et à se démarquer dans la sphère culturelle en vue d'une réelle professionnalisation. Bien que nous ayons la chance de pouvoir compter sur le support de l'École des arts visuels et médiatiques de l'UQAM, la réalisation de l'ensemble de nos projets implique des investissements importants. Afin que notre exposition finale soit un franc succès, nous devons aller chercher des fonds supplémentaires. C'est là que vous entrez en jeu!



Nous supporter

L'exposition sera une occasion extraordinaire pour chacun de nous de faire connaître son travail. Grâce à vos contributions, nous espérons atteindre un résultat à la hauteur de nos ambitions.

Voici, à titre d'exemple, nos dépenses les plus substantielles:

   •   Préparation de l'espace d'exposition (construction et peinture)
   •   Organisation d'événements dans le cadre de l'exposition
   •   Transport et conservation des œuvres
   •   Installation des œuvres
   •   Impression d'affiches promotionnelles
   •   Conception, production et distribution des publications

Le projet est de grande envergure. C'est pourquoi votre aide nous est si précieuse.


Nos partenaires

Nous tenons à souligner le précieux soutien que nous offrent nos partenaires. Sans leur générosité et leur implication dans cette aventure, rien de tout ceci ne serait possible.

Nous remercions chaleureusement

  • Stéphane Gilot
  • Alun Williams
  • Éloïse Plamondon Pagé
  • Bénédicte Ramade
  • Gilles St-Armand
  • Jean-Pierre Gilbert
  • Michèle Picard
  • Louise Déry
  • Julie Bélisle
  • Audrey Genois
  • Marie-Josée Parent
  • Caroline Boileau
  • Linda Gallot
  • Gilles Renaud
  • Alain Paiement
  • L’École des Arts Visuels et Médiatiques
  • Service à la vie étudiante
  • Initiative POUR un espace de diffusion et d’expérimentation du premier cycle en arts visuels et médiatiques
  • Galerie de l'UQAM
  • CDEx
  • Pied Carré
  • Ateliers Créatifs
  • Musique de la vidéo composé par Rivver : soundcloud.com/rivvermusic

N'oublions pas...

... de parler de Cas de figure! Au delà des dons, nous comptons sur vous pour faire connaître notre initiative dans votre entourage et sur les réseaux sociaux.

story:
My name is Aaron Stromberg.

I am a local Albuquerque artist whom some of you may know as the talkative dude at Stone Age Climbing Gym.

Recently, The Nob Hill Neighborhood Association and Nob Hill Main Street, a grassroots community organization, awarded me the opportunity to paint a mural in Nob Hill.  The mural is titled “Nob Hill is 100”, and will celebrate the 100th anniversary of this historic neighborhood.  The size is pretty impressive at 800 square feet and will transform the east-facing wall of Satellite Coffee in the Fan Tang parking lot, close to the northwest corner of Central Ave. and Carlisle Blvd. 

Needless to say, I am very honored and excited about this project.  However, before this mural becomes a reality, there is one last challenge that I need to overcome; the budget for art supplies and equipment.  While Bernalillo County has granted a small stipend for this project, it will only be sufficient to cover the time I will spend working on the mural, not the supplies necessary.  So this is where I need your help!

The goal of my campaign is to raise $1,200, which is the estimated cost of paint and materials necessary to complete this monumental public artwork.  To substantiate how I arrived to this amount, I am providing below the itemized list.

I greatly appreciate any donation and I thank each and every one of you generous people from the bottom of my heart for supporting me on this endeavor.  Creating a mural has always been a dream of mine, and with your help, this dream will come true!

Please feel free to visit me while I’m working on this project!  I will be working 4am to 11am, from September 14th until the end of October.  It will be a pleasure to talk to you about the process through which this artwork came to be and the significance of the images I will bring to life.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

-Aaron Stromberg

astrombster@gmail.com

www.coroflot.com/aaronstromberg/portfolio

The Supplies:

  • 100% Acrylic exterior paint:
    • $40 per gallon X 15 gallons = $600
  • Montana Spray Paint:
    • $10 per can X 30 cans= $300
  • Paint Rollers:
    • $10 ea. X 13 rollers= $130
  • Paint Brushes & Small Paint Rollers:
    • $100
  • Masking Tape:
    • $5 ea. X 10 rolls= $50
  • Ground Cloth:
    • $20
Total Cost of Supplies:  $1,200

story:
THE JEAN MOYE “DARK” FUND FOR BLACK WOMEN/FEMMES, + TGNC ARTISTS

 

“If  the Black Woman was free, it would mean everyone would have to be free.”

 --Combahee River Collective

 

“Imagination is justice work.”

--The Nap Ministry

 

WHAT

A fund that creates a safety net, moving towards the purchase of land, to nourish the creative dreams of Black Women/Femme + TGNC Artists so that our labor in the dark space of imagination can be properly compensated, + function as the healing and evolutionary force it is meant to be in the world. 

 

WHY

It has never been more clear that Black people in the United States are in dire need of refuge.  Between being disproportionately affected by COVID-19, and our bodies and neighborhoods being under attack by police and vigilantes, we are in a state of emergency.  As Black women/femme + TGNC artists, visionaries, and healers, we are especially vulnerable to the compounded affects of every system working against us; Brenona Taylor, a Black nurse, was murdered in her sleep, and the police have still not been arrested.  More Black transwomen have been murdered in the first 7 months of 2020 than in the whole of 2019.  And yet, we continue to dream, because we know that global liberation is bound up in ours.  We also continue to demand.  This letter is both a meditation and a call to action. 

We live in a society that loves art, but does not value artists; that loves blackness but not black people; that loves “Queer Eye” but not queerness. When we Black women, femmes, and TGNC folks decide to be artists, that is TO BE FREE, we are already taking a leap inside the impossible.    If we Black women, femmes, and TGNC folks not only make art, but make art that has to do with ourselves, that is, art that does not cater to the white gaze, art that is invested in Black and Indigenous ways of understanding the world, art that is grounded in grassroots and activist organizing, and ultimately, art that is in alignment with LIBERATION + SOVEREIGNTY, there is tremendous social and financial risk, stigma, and punishment. 

Even in the best of times, we often end up working multiple jobs outside of our creative labor, simply to make life work, in addition to the countless days and nights in rehearsal rooms, studios, libraries, and educational settings to push our visions into the world. Much of this is invisible, uncompensated--and even costly--labor. We do not have easy access to inter-generational wealth, health insurance, or government bail-outs.  When tragedy hits, we are hit extra hard, as members of several communities at the intersections of many margins.  

Some of us stop being artists. Some of us continue, wounded and fatigued, but die before our time (Ntozake Shangé, Audre Lorde, June Jordan).  Some of us will not be remembered, having buried what we perceive as our “failed” dreams, and we will guard our descendants the way our elders tried to guard us from stepping out of line.  We become traumatized by  our “poor choices,” when the reality is that we live in a society that does not support artists, let alone Black women, femme, and other TGNC artists.

I am asking us to invest in another future. 


THE STORY

My great-grandmother, Willie “Jean” Moye, a Black-Native woman from Meridian, Mississippi, was a writer. No one knew that this woman who grew up in the first half of the 20th century, who had once run into a burning building to rescue her daughter, was a writer until two decades into the 21st century when a manuscript was discovered in her basement, long after she’d departed this physical world. My great-grandmother spent her life mining a different kind of labor: child-rearing; mending, cleaning, and sewing the clothes of the white and wealthy; and thrifting the clothes and goods they decided were trash.  

I share this not because my great-grandmother’s life was without honor.  She was the most beautiful, kind, and dignified woman I ever met.  But hers is merely one story that illustrates the reality: Black, Women/Femmes + TGNC Folks are systematically excluded from the artists’ path, the road of the dreamer, and it is not for want of dreams.  In this America and all the iterations that came before, it is not safe or viable for us to dream.  It is not safe or viable for us to experience vulnerability or wonder; or to know our own selves as manifestations of the Divine. I’m taking a step to change that and need your help to create a different story than the one my great-grandmother and so many of us still share.

When Black Women, Femmes, and TGNC folks are invested in, we build a new world, in deeper alignment with all of creation. We come from here.

 

THE FUND

The Jean Moye Dark Fund will primarily support the creation of a collectively-imagined residency space that centers Black Women (Cis and Trans), Non-Binary Folks, and other Transfolks to be artists, world-makers, healers, and visionaries.  Our ultimate goal is to purchase land and be self-sustainable by offering our beloved community time and space to vision, recover, and rest from the ongoing trauma of white supremacy, heteronormativity, and transphobia, as they rob us of our ability to be fully well.  We want to offer a spiritual home, and a physical refuge that provides safe and radical space to heal, make, research, grow, celebrate, set goals, build + share skills,  and invest in body care, all while being rooted in African-diaspora architecture, cooking, geo-spatial structures, modes of healing, and ways of knowing.  It is only through offering this kind of restorative space, we believe, that we will be able to fully support the revolutionary bodies and creative visions of our communities.  We are inspired by the incredible work of spaces like Soul Fire Farm (New York), House of Sedulo (Baltimore), Acorn Center for Restoration and Freedom (Georgia), and Denniston Hill (New York) which, in their own respective ways, address similar issues, and will be seeking to learn from and partner with these spaces as we initiate our own unique process and vision.

A portion of the The Jean Moye Dark Fund will also directly support our community of Black women, femmes, and TGNC artists + organizations who have made incredible sacrifices to help reimagine a world in which we are sacred.

We are in search of collaborators, funders, and impact investors, to support us in the purchase and building on land, in full alignment with stewardship commitments with the indigenous folks of that place.  A vision of this magnitude will take at minimum $600,000 to manifest.  We are hoping to raise $1,000,000 over the course of the next 5 years to see this through, so that we can open the doors in 2025!  

Our first fundraising goal is to reach $77,000 in our first 60 days! 

 

HOW TO SUPPORT

DONATE MONEY.  Commit actual resources to this fund, demonstrate your support of All Black Lives, and expand our creative capacity.

BE AN AMBASSADOR.  Research and communicate with donors, corporations, and celebrities: make introductions, or even make an ask on our behalf.  Think of 2 people who you would be willing to make an introduction to that would have a positive impact on our fund. Would you be willing to fundraise on our behalf?  Host a fundraising party?  Let us know and we can set you up with a toolkit.  

SHARE OUR STORY and encourage your folks to support the fund.  We are launching a social media campaign to make available content from performances over the past few years, written reflections, and quotes from my great-grandmother’s manuscript – work that was largely produced with uncompensated or undercompensated labor. It is offered here as an inspiration and modality of exchange, and we hope you will consider it supporting it by donating and spreading the word.  

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/nia.witherspoon 

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/niasoli

 

Thank you for your time and attention. We look forward to creating magic with you!

 

With any questions, or to reach out, please contact Ghrai Devore Stokes at lyfeankh@gmail.com

story:
In short!

Syn Festival Edinburgh is an annual volunteer run multi-arts festival that offers emerging Scotland-based artists the opportunity to introduce and promote their work to wider audiences. This year's festival will focus on raising awareness and funds to support Edinburgh based organisations involved with helping refugees through various art events. 

We cannot achieve this year's goals without your help! 

Syn Festival Edinburgh

Syn Festival is a Greek multi-arts festival. Each year its theme is derived culturally and socially from Greece and is an open invitation to other cultures towards inclusive and timely artistic dialogue in Scotland. The festival showcases a variety of exhibiting and performing arts, including photography, installations, painting, illustration, film, theatre, dance, and music of different genres. A selection of experiential and technique-building art workshops will also be available to the public free of charge.

To date, Syn Festival is a purely volunteer led organization that is open to volunteers from all different ethnic and professional backgrounds. The purpose of the festival is to create a space where members of the vibrant community of artists in Scotland can communicate their work, share their skills and experiences, network, and expand their audience.
Our mission at Syn Festival is to create a scene for art that is of a high standard, while at the same time providing equal opportunities, support, and exposure to all artists. Proceeds from all donations that we receive in our events will go towards supporting organisations and charities that are working in the communities of Scotland and Greece.

But we need your help for that.

As a volunteer led initiative, we rely entirely on our volunteers’ hard work for the realization and success of the festival. What is more, all the wonderful events that take place during the festival are free of charge for the public and we intend to keep it so.

That is why we need your support in order to be able to cover the festival’s running expenses, to keep working on trying to make Syn Festival even bigger and better and to create a cultural hub which will foster artistic exchange between artists and the local community of Edinburgh and to provide support to as many Scotland based artists as possible.

Even the smallest contribution can make a real difference to us.

Spread the word and help us make Syn Festival one of the most notable free festivals in Edinburgh!

 

http://www.synfestivaledinburgh.co.uk/

The purpose of the festival is to create a space where members of the vibrant community of artists in Scotland can communicate their work, share their skills and experiences, network, and expand their audience.Our mission at Syn Festival is to create a scene for art that is of a high standard, while at the same time providing equal opportunities, support, and exposure to all artists. Proceeds from all donations that we receive in our events will go towards supporting organisations and charities that are working in the communities of Scotland and Greece.But we need your help for that.As a volunteer led initiative, we rely entirely on our volunteers’ hard work for the realization and success of the festival. What is more, all the wonderful events that take place during the festival are free of charge for the public and we intend to keep it so.That is why we need your support in order to be able to cover the festival’s running expenses, to keep working on trying to make Syn Festival even bigger and better and to create a cultural hub which will foster artistic exchange between artists and the local community of Edinburgh and to provide support to as many Scotland based artists as possible.Even the smallest contribution can make a real difference to us.Spread the word and help us make Syn Festival one of the most notable free festivals in Edinburgh! http://www.synfestivaledinburgh.co.uk/

story:
MEET THE BUCKS

  • Teddy Fatscher (Co-Founder, Co- Director, Performer)
  • Tommy Schimmel (Co-Founder, Co-Director, Performer)
  • Dave Morreale (Co-Founder, Executive Producer)
  • Misha King (Performer, Experience Engineer)
  • Jake Van Horn (Performer, Experience Engineer)
  • William Burden (Performer, Experience Engineer)

As a team, The Bucks transform the upstairs club at Franky Bradleys to create intimate one-of-a-kind experiences that our audiences can see, feel and, for this year's fringe, taste. This campaign would disallow restrictions and bring the Buck's vision to fruition.

Here's the skinny on what your funding will help with:

  • building our set and props that we will use to completely transform the venue.
  • buying and building costumes
  • paying our dancers for the time spent developing and performing our work.
  • paying our two sound engineers (who have created an entirely original sound score for this project)
  • providing food for our audiences to enjoy while attending our shows.
  • paying for promotion and advertising (posters, flyers, and the graphic designer who created them)
  • establishing a merchandise inventory to provide future funding and promotional items (Hats, T-shirts and Hoodies)
  • creating and providing the unique perks for our backers who we can't do this without (see perks section of this campaign)

 

Impact

We are Sophomores to Philadelphia Fringe Festival. Last years production "JUNGLE" was a show that many thought would be impossible to achieve in such an intimate space and many who attending were amazed by the transformation of the space. Although this is only our second Fringe Production, we regularly put on shows at this venue. Fringe is different however. The magnitude of this festival is huge for artists and audiences of the city alike. Therefore, the show needs to be bigger and better then the last. I mean, that is our mantra and we are sticking to it."Raising the bar in Philadelphia".

Risks & Challenges

There are a few risks and challenges associated with this production. Most aren't worth mentioning because they are consistent with any production or idea that creators are building. However, there are some unique risks and challenges that come with this show. Here's some of them.

  • Our budget for this show is much higher then any other show. It lands just shy of $10,000. I know this campaign is only just over half of that. However, we are taking into account our average ticket sales for the run of the show and we are confident that we can make up the difference and actually show a net to invest in future productions of the Bucks.
  • We have contracted multiple artists for the first time ever (5 Dancers and 2 Sound Engineers). This contract guarantees the artists a certain wage that we, as directors and producers, will be held accountable for. This is a nerve-racking first for us because normally we calculate artist wages based on ticket sales. Your not just backing The Bucks but your backing our team as well.

Other Ways You Can Help

To ask someone to open up their wallet and invest is asking a lot. For some it is asking the impossible and that is more then understandable. However, if your reading this you have the capability of sharing and making noise about this campaign. Whether you back us or not please share this to anyone and everyone and help the Bucks continue to raise the bar in Philadelphia. Oh yea! Buy a ticket and come see the show!

story:
We are Regardless,

Established by Emma Escamilla and Jared Walters, both with different mediums of art but yet with a similar vision and the  passion to relate to other artists through creative thinking and collaborative efforts while maintaining their own individuality.
 

What We Need
 

We have worked tirelessly on this project for the past 2 years and with your generous donations we can purchase the necessary materials to make Regardless the proper platform for dedicated and skillful artists from all elements. Essential materials like a Heat-Press and a Silkscreen for our Regardless clothing line, photographic supplies which are necessary to create and capture high-quality images.
 


Risks & Challenges
 

Although launching Regardless has been quite a challenge much like any business at the primary stage,we are confident in our partnership, resourcefulness and possess the potential to connect with others to create a successful business that benefits artists both on the amateur and professional level.
Naturally, there is always the fear of our venture being a total loss and having wasted years on this project but "...failure is not an option".




Impact

With your support, we will use this platform to reach others through our work and inspire, for the "love of art" and community.

We are Regardless.
